## Behemoth as a Trickster and Symbol in The Master and Margarita

Behemoth the Cat is a character from the novel The Master and Margarita by the Russian writer Mikhail Bulgakov. He is an enormous (said to be as large as a hog) demonic black cat who speaks, walks on two legs, and can even transform to human shape for brief periods.

### Trickster Characteristics

Behemoth is a trickster, a joker, a mischief maker. He's naughty, sarcastic and at times cruel – an indestructible shape-shifter who doesn't always know when to stop.(no content)He has a penchant for chess, vodka, pistols, and obnoxious sarcasm.(no content)Bulgakov's Behemoth comically combines philosophical ponderings and manners with roguishness and aggressiveness.(no content)He is a gun-toting, chandelier-swinging menace who has a penchant for setting things on fire.

### Symbolic Significance

**Biblical and Literary Origins**: In Russian his name is Бегемот, which can refer to both the Russian name for a hippopotamus or the Biblical beast, who was depicted as a primeval chaos-monster. As portrayed by Bulgakov, he is mostly the latter.(no content)In the Bible, Behemoth is an example of an incomprehensible godly creation and one of the traditional names for a demon, Satan's sidekick.

**Cultural Symbolism**: In The Master and Margarita, Behemoth is a black cat. In the old popular beliefs of large parts of North America and Europe, black cats bring bad luck, and are often associated with witches.

**Transformation and Role**: In chapter 32 of The Master and Margarita, when the demonic characters are transformed again to their original corporeal form, Behemoth changes into a slim youth, a demon-page, and «the best jester the world has ever seen».

### Analysis of His Function

Behemoth is huge black cat who can do everything that a human can do, including talking and walking on his hind legs. He is the most devilish of Woland's crew and delights in causing havoc.(no content)He is evidently the least-respected member of Woland's entourage; Margarita boldly takes to slapping Behemoth on the head after one of his many ill-timed jokes, without fear of retribution.(no content)Woland's assistants — a giant talking cat (Behemoth), a beautiful vampire (Hella), a hitman with a single fang (Azazello), and a grotesque valet (Koroviev) — wreak havoc on the city. The artists and writers of MASSOLIT, members of high society, are swept up in the chaos that this devilish entourage creates in a series of black magic, tricks, embarrassment, and gruesome murders, and many are brought to shame.

### Personal Inspiration

He is also meant to be based on a real life grey cat named Flyushka that Bulgakov and his second wife, Lyubov Evgenevna Belozerskaya (1895-1987) lived with at the time.

Behemoth serves as both comic relief and a symbol of chaos in Bulgakov's critique of Soviet society, embodying the unpredictable and subversive forces that challenge authoritarian control through mischief and supernatural intervention.
